comments:
Human Chronobiology and Sleep covers basic principles of chronobiology; neuroscience mechanisms of circadian rhythms and sleep; phylogeny and ontengeny of sleep; human sleep and sleep disorders; circadian dysfunction; circadian and sleep homeostatic influences in human health and safety.

Overall the course was enjoyed by the students who called it “amazing” and the lectures “absolutely fascinating”. One student did wish that there was more of a focus on the molecular biology behind sleep.

Students as a whole raved about Professor Dinges. Several called him one of the best professors they have ever had, describing him as “awesome,” “fantastic” and “excellent.” He is renowned in his field, made the topics clear and engaging, and he not only stuck to the curriculum, but he also provided life lessons.

One student described the difficulty of the class as “not too easy, not too hard.” BIBB 109 is a prerequisite for this course. Students should be aware that they may not use both BIBB 040 and 240 towards BIBB major or minor.
